comments.body: Maybe this should be a warning since you check it in other places and never use invalid ips?

Are you sure, shouldn't the play fail if an invalid address is specified?
The checks on other places are just to avoid weird behaviours, even though they should never be hit.
This one is part of ansible play error handling.
If there is a list of IPs and some are bad I would want to get a warning and set the good ones as a user, but that's just me
One could (and I think also should) use the ip address jinja2 filters to validate and if you hardcoded values at least I want it to stick to a fail fast and fail forward approach...

@jborean93 curious what you think about this. After our discussion on checking for properties I realized `Get-AnsibleParam` fits the bill nicely, and its description seems to do exactly what I needed. Only issue was that it requires `.ContainsKey()` on the object, even though the rest of the logic works perfectly with both objects and `[hashtable]`s, so it's helpful for these situations operating in strict mode.

If you think this is more widely useful I'd be open to moving it into `Ansible.ModuleUtils.Legacy`, or updating the logic in `Get-AnsibleParam` to just work with both objects and dictionaries.

The Legacy module util is effectively read only and we should only be adding bug fixes and not new features to the module. The proper replacement is the `Ansible.Basic.cs` C# util which uses an interface that is similar to how Python modules work in Ansible (and adds a lot more features to a module).
